facts: Sharks have been around for over 400 million years, before trees existed.
Most sharks must keep swimming to breathe, but some can rest on the ocean floor.
Sharks can detect a single drop of blood in an Olympic-sized pool.
A shark's skeleton is made entirely of cartilage, not bone.
Some sharks can glow in the dark through bioluminescence.
The whale shark is the largest fish in the world, growing up to 40 feet long.
Sharks lose and replace thousands of teeth throughout their lifetime.
A great white shark can detect electrical fields as small as half a billionth of a volt.
Sharks have no vocal cords and cannot make any sounds.
The cookiecutter shark bites circular chunks out of much larger animals.
Some shark species can live over 100 years, with Greenland sharks living 400+ years.
Sharks can sense prey from over 800 feet away using special organs called ampullae of Lorenzini.
A shark's skin feels like sandpaper because it's covered in tiny tooth-like scales.
The dwarf lantern shark is so small it can fit in your hand.
Sharks don't have eyelids, but some have a protective membrane that covers their eyes.
Great white sharks can leap up to 10 feet out of the water when hunting seals.
Sharks have been known to enter a trance-like state called tonic immobility when flipped upside down.
The hammerhead shark's unusual head shape helps it detect prey hiding in sand.
